fields.description: Include some small grey description text underneath variable values that override global variable values. This should display the variable being overridden.
fields.summary: Add a flag/text when a plan variable is overriding a global variable

fields.description:
# Deployment project creation / edit screen
** add a branch selector. Auto complete.
*** Will need a new rest endpoint! All the rest.
** prefilled with whatever the default plan is.
** update backend so that this relationship can be made
fields.summary: Allow source plan to be linked to another branch other than master/default

fields.description:
# Extend exisitng "After successful plan" trigger
** configuration
*** selection of branch of plan configured in deployment project
*** if persisted configuration will contain plan branch key make sure it is updated during move plan operation (/)
** execution
*** when this trigger type is executed, deployment should use artifacts from plan branch result that fired the trigger (/)
*** on branch deletion such trigger should be removed (/)
** Remove the option to change the plan
# Extend existing "Scheduled trigger":
** configuration
*** selection of branch of plan configured in deployment project
*** if persisted configuration will contain plan branch key make sure it is updated during move plan operation (/)
** execution
*** when this trigger type is executed, deployment should use artifacts from plan branch result that fired the trigger (/)
*** on branch deletion such trigger should be removed (/)

To be consistent we should show a label with the linked source plan
fields.summary: Update triggers to automatically deploy a new release from a branch

fields.description:
As usual in programming you chase bugs for an hour and in the end it's a typo :-(


I configured an ant task to compile a project in a sub directory, i.e. I've set the working sub directory in the ant-task configuration.

The build log displays which ant command is executed with the used environment variables and in which directory (working sub directory) the command is executed.

If the working directory does not exist, Bamboo just prints a rather generic error message:
v 5.0: _com.atlassian.bamboo.task.TaskException: Failed to execute task_
v 5.1.1: _Failing task since return code of [.../ant...] was -1 while expected 0_

I'd like to propose the addition of a check to ensure the working directory exists prior to executing the ant task.
fields.summary: Better Error handling for non-existing ant working sub directory

fields.description:
I would recommend that when a plan scheduled or in the process of being moved, that it be locked from:

1. activity - such as builds from running
2. changes (results, plans, jobs, branches) from being deleted or added
3. from the plan being moved again in a second process / window
fields.summary: Apply the following locks for moving Bamboo plans

fields.description:
Having JIRA and Bamboo integrated, when I make a release from JIRA the value for password variables is not masked (Please check the attached screenshots). 
It's hidden under the build summary and metadata tab in Bamboo, but shows up when trying to override it in JIRA.
fields.summary: Password variable value is not masked when making a release from JIRA

fields.description:
https://wiki.jenkins-ci.org/display/JENKINS/SSH+Slaves+plugin

This is one of the things I really liked about Jenkins...  using such an interface, I could start and stop remote agents through the main interface.  I really feel that this is feasible to implement.
fields.summary: create remote agent launch interface

fields.description:
Setup:
* Bamboo tracks a git repository with {{master}} and {{feature}} branches
* there is a branch plan for {{feature}} so that Bamboo should notify committers about test errors
* someone merges {{master}} into {{feature}} to keep it up to date

Expected behavior: the person performing the merge gets notification about any errors

Actual behavior: everyone who had a commit in master which got merged (in practice this means the whole team) gets notification

Notification is not the only affected component, e.g. the commit list in the "Changes" tab of the build detail view also contains all the commits.
fields.summary: Too many notifications for release -> feature merge in Git plan branches

fields.description:
It would be nice/awesome if bamboo could display the status of the build in the favicon

https://github.com/ejci/favico.js
http://lab.ejci.net/favico.js/
fields.summary: Add favicon.js to Bamboo Builds

fields.description: We've got a build at https://extranet-bamboo.internal.atlassian.com/browse/PERFENG-KOTO which is configured to automatically handle branches. Unfortunately, new branch builds come in disabled and need to be manually enabled before running.
fields.summary: Plan creates disabled branch builds
Add documentation for the VCS Branching and VCS Tagging tasks

fields.description:
When I try to view the URL at https://staging-bamboo.atlassian.com/browse/PUPPETCI-PUPPETCD-154/commit I keep getting an error. I can reproduce this for every build which still has manual stages which haven't been executed yet (e.g. also build -152). Completed builds which had their final manual stages completed display this tab fine (e.g. build -151).

This issue hurts us because it means it's more difficult for us to tell which changes are included in this build before we push it to production.

fields.description:
I installed Bamboo 5.1 for Windows.
In the install folder (C:\Program Files\Bamboo) I found a README.txt file containing references to some sh-scripts.

I do belive this file is supposted to come with the linux version as it is referering to linux-shell-scripts.

It should be removed from the Windows Standalone Installer, as it might confuse people.
fields.summary: Bamboo 5.1 Standalone for Windows contains README.txt for linux

fields.description:
*Issue Description*
In Bamboo 4.4.5, in the home page and if you go to _Wallboard_ you could expand the wallboard upon clicking the wallboard. However this feature breaks in 5.0 and 5.1. Upon further investigating using debugging tools in Chrome, if you navigate to _Console_ tab, this error will come up.
{noformat}
Uncaught Error: Syntax error, unrecognized expression: .build. batch.js:4680
Sizzle.error batch.js:4680
tokenize batch.js:4741
select batch.js:5113
select batch.js:5289
Sizzle batch.js:3937
jQuery.event.dispatch batch.js:3024
elemData.handle.eventHandle batch.js:2676
{noformat}

*Steps to replicate*
# Upon navigation to Home page click _Wallboard >> All Plans_
# Click any of the plan and notice it won't be expanded
fields.summary: Can't expand Wallboard

fields.description:
*Steps to reproduce*
# Create a command task with the path pointing to a shell command say echo for example. See the attached screenshot
# When this is run against an older version of Bamboo, it runs fine despite the error message that "Unable to find executable at echo"
{code}
error	03-Sep-2013 16:58:50	Unable to find executable at echo
command	03-Sep-2013 16:58:50	Beginning to execute external process for build 'TESTA - TSTA - Default Job'\n ... running command line: \necho 2 > sultan.txt\n ... in: D:\atlassian\BAMBOO\atlassian-bamboo-4.4.4\HOME\xml-data\build-dir\TESTA-TSTA-JOB1\n
{code}
# Now if this is done in the latest Bamboo 5.1, it fails with the build logs throwing something like
{code}
error	03-Sep-2013 17:02:19	Unable to find executable at echo
command	03-Sep-2013 17:02:19	Beginning to execute external process for build 'TESTA - TSTA - Default Job #17 (TESTA-TSTA-JOB1-17)'\n ... running command line: \necho 17 > sultan.txt\n ... in: D:\atlassian\BAMBOO\atlassian-bamboo-5.1.0\HOME\xml-data\build-dir\TESTA-TSTA-JOB1\n
simple	03-Sep-2013 17:02:19	Failing task since return code of [echo 17 > sultan.txt] was -1 while expected 0

fields.description:
Encompassing request:
Allow the field to accept branches from its own plan as this is currently not allowed.

Currently:
1) If I have plan 1 with Branch A and plan 2 with Branch B, 
2) When I select Branch B, then the "Only run Build if other Plans are currently passing" checkbox 
3) And enter the plan key of plan 1/Branch A, I get an error in the UI: "MYTESTPROJECT-MYTESTPLAN0 is a job and can not be used in this field."

For scenarios that we want a plan branch to be build only if a specific branch from another plan has completed successfully, it will be helpful if Bamboo could accept the plan-branch key. This appears to work correctly at plan level but it's not currently working at the branch level. In the above example, we want Plan 2-Branch B to only build if Plan1-Branch A is successful.
fields.summary: Make it possible to run a branch only if a branch from a different plan is built successfully

fields.description:
Currently users are able to select their preferred AWS Region from Elastic Bamboo 'Configuration'
The default images within the Bamboo documentation are only available from US East (Northern Virginia).

*Current:*
Login to AWS console
Find the Community AMI (these cannot be copied across regions)
Create an AMI based on the community AMI
Copy across to the desired region 

*Improved:*
The default Community AMI's are made available for all regions

The Affects Version for OnDemand does not allow the correct version to be added:  5.0.2-OD-2
fields.summary: Bamboo to provide default stock images on all AWS regions

fields.description:
From [Amazon|http://aws.amazon.com/ebs/]:

bq. To enable your Amazon EC2 instances to fully utilize the IOPS provisioned on an EBS volume, you can launch selected Amazon EC2 instance types as “EBS-Optimized” instances. EBS-optimized instances deliver dedicated throughput between Amazon EC2 and Amazon EBS, with options between 500 Mbps and 1000 Mbps depending on the instance type used. When attached to EBS-Optimized instances, Provisioned IOPS volumes are designed to deliver within 10% of the provisioned IOPS performance 99.9% of the time. 

Mousing-over the Instance Type on the Image Configurations page in admin will say whether the EBS-optimised is available for that instance type, but you can't actually use opt to use that anywhere.
fields.summary: Add support for using EBS-optimised volumes

fields.description:
I just upgraded from Bamboo 5.0.1 to 5.1 and noticed that my remote agent did not come back online after the upgrade.

Looking at the remote agent's log, I notice a long stack trace with the following exception: java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: org/slf4j/LoggerFactory happening over and over. 
I tried reinstalling the remote agent, but it still does not seem to include the necessary jars.

Stack trace attached.
fields.summary: Missing SLF4J dependency for Remote Agent in 5.1

fields.description:
If I have a plugin with the following in the atlassian-plugin.xml - the admin ui starts 500:ing. Adding the linkId attribute fixes it.
{code}
    <web-item key="my-special-web-item" section="system.admin">
        <label key="Main Configuration"/>
        <link>/foo</link>
    </web-item>
{code}

This wouldn't normally be that bad - but it kills the upm interface - thus the only way to fix it is to rm the jar from the disk and then restart Bamboo...

According to:
https://developer.atlassian.com/display/DOCS/Web+Item+Plugin+Module#WebItemPluginModule-LinkElements : linkId is optional....
fields.summary: web-item's with missing linkId's breaks the admin interface

fields.description:
I have a number of projects which I deploy to multiple AWS environments. The deployment process is identical, save for which environment it goes to, and project-specific details.

As such, I put the project-specific details into the Bamboo build plan as variables, and the environment-specific details into the deployment environment as variables. The tasks then are "cut-and-paste" for uniformity.

This all works great when I create a release from builds that I triggered manually in Bamboo. However, when I create a release from an automatically triggered build, these custom plan variables aren't passed down.
fields.summary: Plan variables don't seem to make it to deployment projects reliably

fields.description:
Since Bamboo 5.1, each new tab contributed by a plugin (like the [Bamboo JMeter Plugin|https://bitbucket.org/atlassian/bamboo-jmeter-plugin]) by specifying the following in the atlassian-plugin.xml:
{code}
<web-item key="jmeterAggregatorReports" name="jmeterAggregatorReports" section="build.subMenu/build" weight="60">
      <label key="Load Test Reports"/>
      <link>/build/viewLoadTestReport.action?buildKey=${buildKey}</link>
      <condition class="com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.jmeter_aggregator.web.BambooLoadTestReportCondition" />
    </web-item>
{code}

Fails to render and the tab content is just blank.
fields.summary: Bamboo 5.1 fails to render custom plan tabs

fields.description:
Hello,

I am maintaining a Bamboo Remote Agent in a company where Bamboo server is maintained centrally by administrators. The Agent is run on Windows as a service. I have no admin access to Bamboo server itself, I can only request for service.

I often myself in a situation where the Remote Agent is unavailable, has been for some time, and I need to manually restart it. There are special capability requirements for the agent, and these are not provided by the other Agents.

According to our Bamboo administrators, there is a timeout for situations when network connection is lost. After the timeout, the Remote Agent stops retrying and shuts down. I see this as a problem. Remote Agent is a backend software, there is not necessarily anyone there to handle the restart. This can cause longer disruption to service than is really necessary.

One can work around this problem by configuring the (windows) service to be restarted automatically. But that will then happen in all error scenarios: configuration errors, Bamboo bugs, etc. And in these cases I would argue that the correct response is to shut down like it currently does. I.e. two error categories would be required. If Remote Agent can recover from error, it should try to do it infinitely. If it cannot recover, it should shut down.

Now, it may be the case that I am misinformed, and this is the way Remote Agent already functions. Maybe there is configuration option or something that I am unaware of. In that case, just let me know, and I'll pass the information along to our admins.

Thanks for your help and feedback,

-Marko
fields.summary: Infinite connection retry for Remote Agents

fields.description: Regular Bamboo builds cannot start if the Bamboo server is paused, but Deployment projects currently can.
fields.summary: Deployment project can run even if the Bamboo server is Paused

fields.description:
Variable values are not getting substituted for deployments when a manual stage is triggered from JIRA. Steps to re-produce:
1. Create a plan in Bamboo with three stages: Stage A, Stage B and Stage C.
2. Make Stage B and Stage C manual.
3. Create a deployment project and make it get triggered when the plan completes.
4. Run the Bamboo plan. It will build stage A and will pause on manual Stage B. 
5. Having Bamboo and JIRA integrated, create a release in JIRA with "Existing Build" and select both manual stages B and C. Then release.
6. Checking the build results in Bamboo, JIRA version is showing up under the Metadata tab for all stages of the plan and if the variable ${bamboo.jira.version} is used in the tasks, it shows up in the logs. But, checking the deployment project that was triggered by this plan, JIRA version doesn't exist under the variables tab and even if the ${bamboo.jira.version} is used in a deployment task, the value is not substituted in the logs.
Check screenshots: JIRAVersion_1.PNG to JIRAVersion_4.PNG.

It's a different scenario if the release is with "New Build". The variable is substituted correctly for all stages and for the deployment as well. 
Check screenshots: JIRAVersion_5.PNG to JIRAVersion_7.PNG.
fields.summary: Variable values are not getting substituted for deployments when triggered from JIRA

fields.summary: Cannot save new elastic instance schedules - NPE

fields.description:
In the OnDemand version of Bamboo, deployments do not seem to start elastic instances. They will use one if it is available, but will not start one if there isn't - even if there are _no_ instances available.

This is making scheduled deployments useless for me - I've set up scheduled deployments to populate our test environments early in the morning, and they just stay queued until an elastic instance is available.
fields.summary: Deployments do not start an elastic instance

fields.description:
I followed the excellent Atlassian SDK tutorial and made a skeleton plugin for bamboo:

$ atlas-create-bamboo-plugin

....
[INFO] Sending event to Google Analytics: AMPS:bamboo - SDK First Run - 4.2.9
[INFO] determining latest stable product version...
[INFO] using latest stable product version: 5.1
[INFO] determining latest stable data version...
[INFO] using latest stable data version: 3.2.2
...

When I try to atlas-run I eventually get:

Missing:
----------
1) org.apache.struts:struts2-core:jar:2.3.15.1-atlassian-5

  Try downloading the file manually from the project website.

  Then, install it using the command: 
      mvn install:install-file -DgroupId=org.apache.struts -DartifactId=struts2-core -Dversion=2.3.15.1-atlassian-5 -Dpackaging=jar -Dfile=/path/to/file

  Alternatively, if you host your own repository you can deploy the file there: 
      mvn deploy:deploy-file -DgroupId=org.apache.struts -DartifactId=struts2-core -Dversion=2.3.15.1-atlassian-5 -Dpackaging=jar -Dfile=/path/to/file -Durl=[url] -DrepositoryId=[id]

  Path to dependency: 
  	1) com.atlassian.bamboo.tutorial:helloworld:atlassian-plugin:1.0-SNAPSHOT
  	2) com.atlassian.bamboo:atlassian-bamboo-web:jar:5.1
  	3) org.apache.struts:struts2-core:jar:2.3.15.1-atlassian-5

2) org.apache.struts.xwork:xwork-core:jar:2.3.15.1-atlassian-7

  Try downloading the file manually from the project website.

  Then, install it using the command: 
      mvn install:install-file -DgroupId=org.apache.struts.xwork -DartifactId=xwork-core -Dversion=2.3.15.1-atlassian-7 -Dpackaging=jar -Dfile=/path/to/file

  Alternatively, if you host your own repository you can deploy the file there: 
      mvn deploy:deploy-file -DgroupId=org.apache.struts.xwork -DartifactId=xwork-core -Dversion=2.3.15.1-atlassian-7 -Dpackaging=jar -Dfile=/path/to/file -Durl=[url] -DrepositoryId=[id]

  Path to dependency: 
  	1) com.atlassian.bamboo.tutorial:helloworld:atlassian-plugin:1.0-SNAPSHOT
  	2) com.atlassian.bamboo:atlassian-bamboo-web:jar:5.1
  	3) com.atlassian.bamboo:atlassian-bamboo-core:jar:5.1
  	4) org.apache.struts.xwork:xwork-core:jar:2.3.15.1-atlassian-7

----------
2 required artifacts are missing.


When I change the pom.xml to "5.0" or "4.0" everything goes great, I can load the bamboo plugin list and see my "helloworld" guy in there.
fields.summary: missing struts dependencies in 5.1 SDK.   5.0 & 4.0 OK

fields.description:
Since Bamboo 5.1 is using Tomcat, we decided to not ship the WAR version to simplify the installation process. But since the package exists for all previous versions it's causing confusion. Please add a note to the download page: https://www.atlassian.com/software/bamboo/download and/or the installation/upgrade documents that explains this: https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Bamboo+installation+guide
https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Bamboo+generic+upgrade+guide
fields.summary: Leave a note on the downloads page and the installation documents about the missing WAR package

fields.description:
I was able to reproduce this behavior. Here are the steps:

 confirmed the deletion from the ARTIFACT table is a bug after plans have been moved. Below are the steps I used to reproduce the issue.

1. Performed a few builds in 2 different plans (each having artifacts configured) in 2 different projects.
2. Verified the records were in the ARTIFACT table
3. Deleted one result manually through the Bamboo UI. Bamboo correctly removed the record from ARTIFACTS table.
4. Configured build expiry, and it also correctly removed the record from ARTIFACT table.
5. Moved one of the plans from its project to the other project with a new key. Confirmed old ARTIFACT record was there (using the original PLAN_KEY).
6. Deleted the moved result and plan, but the ARTIFACT record still remained there and was not deleted.

(Maybe we should update the PLAN_KEY on the ARTIFACT table when a plan is moved?)
fields.summary: ARTIFACT table doesn't get cleaned when a plan is moved to a different project

fields.summary: Stack trace when viewing an associated release in the build plan summary on the right side frame

fields.description: Currently Bamboo publishes artifacts even if the build fails. Add a new feature (maybe a checkbox) to allow changing this behavior.
fields.summary: Option not to publish artifacts when the build fails
Bamboo installer should automatically set the file and system encoding to utf-8

fields.description:
We need to have an equivalent of bamboo.buildTimeStamp that is available during deployment.

This should be the time of when the first job in the plan started executing.
fields.summary: bamboo.buildTimeStamp for deployment projects

fields.description:
Link in "Please add the following parameters to Bamboo" is broken.

https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Monitor+Memory+usage+and+Garbage+Collection+in+Bamboo?src=search
fields.summary: Broken Link

fields.description:
If you have a variable in the branch name for your default plan, bamboo tries to evaluate it before showing in the Branch selector.  However it uses the plan/branch you a looking at to evaluate the variable rather than the actual plan its representing.

e.g.
PLAN -> Branch set to "$\{bamboo.branch.name}" -> branch.name set to "default"
PLAN-BRANCH -> Branch set to "mybranch" -> branch.name set to "mybranch"

When viewing the plan, the branch selector shows two options default and mybranch.  When viewing the branch, the selector shows mybranch twice.
fields.summary: Branch selector uses branches variables when substituting plan's branch name.
"Do not block" option in dependency blocking should be selected by default

fields.description: Ability to provide custom variables at run time when deploying a release to an environment
fields.summary: Parameterised variables for Deployment environments

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Bamboo doesn't support more utilizing Elastic Bamboo in more than one AWS region at a time. 

h3. Suggested Solution

Implement the ability to configure images or instance types to utilize a different region or even multiple regions of which one can be used as a failover in the event the service is unavailable in that region.
fields.summary: Support multiples AWS regions at the same time.

fields.description:
As a developer I would like to push a branch to a git server and have it validated against a bamboo plan which notifies me and/or to my stash instance in the time that it takes to run the plan (or reasonable wait on a queue).

At present I need to wait up to 5 minutes for the "Automatically manage branches" feature to recognise the new branch before the plan is started.

Please make the detection of new branches time configurable.
fields.summary: Configurable time for detection of new branches for "Automatically manage branches" feature

fields.description:
notice strange A character and notice that cursor is moved by two characters to the left, this is also wrong, cursor is at the end.

when I copy text everithing is ok, when I execute it in bamboo, its ok also. only display is corupted
fields.summary: inline task script editor has problems with spaces

fields.description:
by default catalina_home is set to %cd%, when bamboo is installed in c:\Program Files\Bamboo execution is broken

as a workaround I set in environment variables catalina_home to c:\progra~1\bamboo
around script name you miss ""
powershell -ExecutionPolicy bypass -Command script_name [script_options]
fields.summary: Space in catalina_home variable breaks execution of inline powershell script task

fields.description:
The REST request returns HTML then the JSON parser barfs expecting valid JSON. If it gets invalid JSON it should have a cleaner failure message. {quote} Bamboo Rest Request failed, could not parse response from BAMBOO (bitbucket.atlassian.net):A JSONObject text must begin with '{' at character 10 of You have not been granted access to Bamboo. - Bitbucket JIRA

fields.summary: Error in "Issue deployment" web panel when user does not have access to Bamboo

fields.description:
We have a project that has released versions that we want to get notifications send to a mailing list, and we want to have notifications for all builds (successful as well as failure) be send to the committers. Right now we can only send emails on failures and first success.

It would be nice to to be to use the same nice notification system for new automatic branches (as well as existing branches).
fields.summary: Advanced configuration of notifications for branches

fields.description:
The updateAndBuild.action URL in Bamboo is used to ask Bamboo to conditionally build. When using [repository triggers|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Repository+triggers+the+build+when+changes+are+committed], this is the only way to ensure that the build isn't run every time and instead respects the options laid out in [plan branching|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Using+plan+branches] and [advanced repository configuration|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Git].

If one uses the [build queue service|https://docs.atlassian.com/bamboo/REST/5.0-SNAPSHOT/#d2e927], all options and restrictions are ignored, forcing a manual build. This is especially problematic for users using Bitbucket and OnDemand as this means _every_ push to Bitbucket (which uses the queue API) will trigger the build, which costs users money using EC2, as it is the only way to build in Bamboo OnDemand.

This URL should either be changed/added to the REST API or documented well so that users can use it. This issue kind of depends on BAM-13699, which is linked.
fields.summary: updateAndBuild.action should have a REST API endpoint and/or be documented

fields.description:
It is currently _impossible_ to set any kind of whitelist in Bamboo as ALL requests inbound appear to come from the proxy to Bamboo. OnDemand uses an http header that explicitly provides the correct inbound customer IP address. 

Due to this issue, you cannot utilize the updateAndBuild.action URL that customers are instructed to use in the [scripts provided|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Repository+triggers+the+build+when+changes+are+committed#Repositorytriggersthebuildwhenchangesarecommitted-1.Configuringyoursourcerepository].
fields.summary: OnDemand Bamboo should respect the X-FORWARDED-FOR http header when checking the whitelist

fields.description:
Every Atlassian application has different scripts formats and workflow. We should have a common format guidelines to make them consistent between applications.

This will bring us the following wins:
* Sysadmins of Atlassian products will be able to configure any product in the same way, reducing the learning curve.
* Some pages in the documentation (and also the KB space) would be valid for all products, making them easier to maintain.

I personally like the way the files are formatted in JIRA (and Bamboo) but we should agree in a common format.
fields.summary: Get consistent start, stop, configuration and installation scripts across Atlassian products

fields.description:
h4. Issue Description
When the deployment is tight to a plan and upon the relase of the build to the deployment, artifacts that are tight to the plan should be available for the deployment as well. However the artifact that has variable on its name, is not available for the deployment. 

h4. Steps to replicate
# Create a test plan.
# Create a deployment that is tight to the test plan.
# Make sure the plan has its source repository and make sure the repository has some file inside.
# Create two artifact definitions to certain job in that test plan.
# Make sure both artifact definitions have different name while the other one include variable on its name, despite of having  same copy pattern. For example:
!artifact-definition.png!
# Create some simple task in that plan and build the plan.
# Upon the completion of the build, check out the _Artifacts_ tab in Build summary and you will notice the following.
!plan-artifacts.png!
# Go back to _Build Summary_ tab and click _Create Release_ button.
# Notice that in the deployment summary, the artifact with variable on its name won't be included inside _Release Contents_.
!deployment-artifact.png!
fields.summary: Artifact is not included in the deployment if the name of artifact contains variable

fields.description:
Stages being run by Bamboo in different local or remote agents is an expected behavior as mentioned in this doc - https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/stage
bq. Processes its jobs in parallel, on multiple agents (where available).

However, this feature is breaking builds using elastic agent especially Bamboo OnDemand.

h3. Example Scenario
* The first stage will run job that will checkout codes from repositories into EC2.
* Second stage consists jobs that will run tests. If the jobs are are going to be executed using different elastic agent, it means it will run on a totally different EC2 instance. Data from first stage won't be available.

This feature should be disabled for elastic agents.
fields.summary: Stages run in different elastic agents causing builds failure

fields.description:
On 8/26, our elastic builds began to fail with the message:

/mnt/bamboo-ebs/elasticbeanstalk-cli/bin/../lib/aws/client/awsqueryhandler.rb:1:in `require': no such file to load -- rubygems (LoadError)

We are using the stock Elastic Bamboo instance:

AMI idami-0a4d3f63
EBS volume / snapshot idsnap-7eb11338

It looks as if the stock image has been modified to no longer come with 'rubygems' installed. Would be fine except the Amazon distro dependencies are also broken and installing the rubygems package on the host instance leads to dependency errors. We could potentially workaround by forcing a downgrade to ruby and ruby-libs in order to allow the installation of rubygems. The workaround is fragile and it would be far better if the elastic host image and/or amazon distro was fixed.

We have also opened an issue with Amazon re. the broken distro.

Our hosted URL is:

https://consumersunion.atlassian.net

It's not clear whether this report should be filed here or under the 'Atlassian Support' project so I have done both.

https://support.atlassian.com/browse/JST-74820
fields.summary: Elastic Bamboo host fails to initialize.

fields.description: The current build expiry system allows you to clean old (and sometimes large) log files from your Bamboo server, but the settings do not affect remote hosts. fields.description:
*Issue Description*
Two deployment on different environment will generate different version despite they are triggered from the same build. This should generate same version as it would be incoherent to generate different release despite they are from same build.

*Steps to Replicate*
# Create a simple plan
# Create two different environment for deployment from same plan
# Make sure to put trigger _After Successful Plan_ for both environment
# Run the plan and upon successful notice the version of the deployment will be incremented
fields.summary: Version of deployment on different environment should be retained if they are from the same build

fields.description:
In OnDemand users can be granted application access separate from the usual Bamboo permissions. However this causes an error in JIRA when the user has not been given application access to Bamboo and views an issue.

 The following error shows: {{Bamboo Rest Request failed, could not parse response from BAMBOO (instance url):A JSONObject text must begin with '{' at character 10 of}}

*steps to reproduce*
# Create a new User in OnDemand
# Give them Application Access to JIRA only.
# Log in with the new user and browse to a JIRA issue.
The error message is now shown in the panel.

*Workaround*
* Grant Bamboo access to all your users in OnDemand
or
* Affected users can collapse the panel to hide this error message
or
* Contact [Atlassian Support|https://support.atlassian.com] and ask for the _Deployment Panel_ module of the Bamboo plugin to be disabled. This can only be done by support as the Bamboo plugin is a system plugin and cannot be modified by normal administrators.
fields.summary: The Bamboo Deployments Panel shows an error in JIRA if the user does not have application Access.
not something we can merge error when using branch updater merging strategy with repository caching enabled

fields.description:

It will be great if we can have this option extended not only to paused builds but to completed builds.

fields.description: Frequently when debugging new builds or debugging changes to builds (happens more often than I'd like.) I find I need to make variable or script changes (remove an end slash or correct the order of arguments in a script or command task).  If I rebuild a failed task it does not reload from the variables, and if I rerun the entire build it doesn't reload from the scripts.  (I may be somewhat confused on this because it seems that sometimes it does and sometimes it doesn't).  It would reduce the number of failed builds during testing if I could force a reload of scripts and variables during a rebuild or rerun of failed tasks.  And it would also save a LOT of time.
fields.summary: Allow reload of all variables and scripts on rebuild
